seg.seg: The good reputation of the energetic ones spreads to all corners of the world; With energy, one will receive honour, appreciation, ovations and adulation from everyone,
Der gute Ruf der Energischen verbreitet sich in den zehn Weltgegenden.
The good reputation of those that have energy spreads over the ten directions
one will soon overcome the enemies and soon attain prosperity. 1. The energetic ones have many possessions, the energetic ones [also have] many followers,
to the energetic ones the enemies submit, to the energetic ones distinction comes,
the energetic ones [are] the protection of the beings, the energetic ones do not know fear. Therefore energy is good and superior to all in my opinion. 2.

Durch seine Energie stieg da in früherer Zeit der Sohn des Königs Siddhārtha, der Bodhisattva Sarvārthasiddha, zum Ozean herab, ... ging sieben Tage lang bis zum Hals im Wasser, ... ging sieben Tage lang im Schlamm und ging, nachdem er sieben Tage lang im Wasser mit tausendblättrigen Lotusblumen von Lotus zu Lotus steigend (gegangen) war, fünf Meilen weit auf von Schlangen bedeckter Erde. ... Dann überschritt er die vierfachen, mit Schlangen bedeckten Festungsgräben [und] nachdem er [auch] die Netze mit vierfachen Fäden (?) aus Bergkristall(?) [und] die großen, furchtbaren Nāgas, die den Palast des Königs Sāgara bewachten, durchschritten hatte, erlangte er schließlich(?) vom König Sāgara das Cintāmaṇi-Juwel.

Due to his energy, in a former time, the son of the king Siddhārtha, the bodhisattva Sarvārthasiddha, descended to the ocean, ... [he] went in the water up to his neck, for seven days, ... [he] went in the mud for seven days and, after having (gone) stepping from lotus to lotus in the water, with lotuses of a thousand leaves, he went five miles over ground covered with snakes. ... Then he passed over the fourfold moats covered with snakes [and] after passing the nets [made] from fourfold threads)?) of mountain crystal(?) [and] the huge, dreadful Nāgas who guard the palace of king Sāgara, he finally (?) obtained the Cintāmaṇi-jewel from the king Sāgara.
Due to his energy, then, in earlier times the son of the king Siddhārta, the Bodhisattva Sarvārthasiddha [“he succeeds in everything”] came down to the ocean [and] went to the island of jewels.
(After having loaded? the ship) with pearls and [after having] dismissed the caravan to Jambudvīpa, during seven days he went up to the neck in water, seven days he (swam?) with his arms,
during seven days he went over mud, moving around for seven days, stepping from one lotus to another, in a water with lotuses with a thousand leaves
five miles he went over the ground covered with snakes. Then he went to the island of the Rākṣasas, then to that of the Yakṣas, (then)
to Baladvīpa. Thereupon he crossed the moats covered with four kinds of snakes, the four-fold nets, made by
strings (?) of crystal, past the great [and] terrible Nāgas, who watched the palace of king Sāgara,
he moved, and finally obtained as reward the cintāmaṇi-jewel from king Sāgara; the poverty of the whole Jambudvīpa
he made disappear. Thus it is said: || In the Ṣ.-tune: || The energetic ones cross the ocean that is hard to traverse, the threefold world
